title: New York City Ballet Fall Gala Raises $2.67 Million, Celebrates Ballet And Fashion
text: [gallery2012] New York City Ballet held its Fall Gala Wednesday night at the David Koch Theater, raising $2.67 million for the company. This marks the fourth year NYCB has collaborated with fashion designers to create costumes for individual ballets. NYCB board member Sarah Jessica Parker conceived the idea several years ago, and in 2012, Valentino was the first designer to design costumes in collaboration with choreographers at NYCB. This year, Peter Copping of Oscar de la Renta, Hanako Maeda of Adeam, Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony and Kenzo, Zuhair Murad, and Marta Marques and Paolo Almeida of Marques Almeida brought forth their personal fashion touches."It was a challenge, because I wasn't designing fashion," said Copping, who worked alongside NYCB Ballet Master In Chief Peter Martins for the ballet he choreographed, Thou Swell . "This had a different set of rules. It was very much a collaboration between Oscar de la Renta and NYCB. Their team is fantastic; I really listened to them and had a lot to learn. I wanted it to reflect the house of Oscar de la Renta, and it was very glamorous, very lavish - all that Oscar loved. I feel proud and rewarded by the result."Guests, including Jennifer Hudson, Rose McGowan, Jill Kargman, Fe Fendi and Donya Bommer enjoyed a pre-performance reception featuring Ruinart champagne, the official champagne of NYCB. Parker and philanthropist Adrienne Arsht chaired the evening. [entity display="Cartier" type="organization" subtype="company" active="true" key="cartier" natural_id="fred/company/102428"]Cartier[/entity] was the corporate sponsor."NYCB is an innovative company; it just celebrated its 50th anniversary," said Nicolas Ricroque, Ruinart's Brand Director. "They have cultivated elegance, purity and sophistication, which are values that we share at Ruinart."Kargman, whose Bravo show, Odd Mom Out , will be returning for a second season, is a big fan."This is pure art and artistry, it's just like a painting come to life," said Kargman, whose mother, Coco Kopelmann, attended the School of American Ballet.Peter Martins was clearly proud of the evening, which seemed so effortless but was actually the end result of months of hard work."When you invite four choreographers to create four new ballets, you never know what you're going to get," said Martins. "It's the great unknown. But we have to take chances. We ended up being pretty lucky. They came up with some wonderful works."
